unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Ice Cream Shop | 3 of 3
question_text:
An owner of a local ice cream shop wishes to determine if a positive linear relationship exists between high temperatures and the shopâ€™s profits recorded that day.
The owner recorded sales from the last $50\text{ days}$ of the summer and performed a linear regression $T$-interval on temperature vs. sales at $95\%$ confidence.
If the interval extends from $50.2$ to $76.2$, which of the following statements is/are true?
I. Strong evidence exists $(p < 0.05)$ of a linear relationship between these variables.
II. The model predicts an extra $\$63.20$ in sales for every extra degree the temperature rises.
III. In this situation specifically, extrapolation is probably safe.
solution:
Statement I is true; since the entire slope is above $0$, strong evidence exists of a relationship. Since this is a $95\%$ confidence interval, $p$ must be less than $0.05$.

Statement II is true; the sample slope is $\frac{(76.2+50.2)}{2} = 63.2$. Per definition of slope, it is the predicted increase in sales for every one extra degree increase in temperature.

Statement III is false; extrapolation is never safe. In this context, at some point, the temperature will be hot enough that sales would decrease as people would not want to be outside or drive to the ice cream shop.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
